summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment in favor of the parents of three severely disabled children who were left out of school for several years because of DOE's failure to provide them with IEP-related services.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Brooklyn, New York, the Department of Education (DOE) and Department of Health and Human Services (OHHS) failed to provide timely and appropriate IEP services to their children.  The complaint alleges that the DOE's policies and procedures were so inconsistent and widespread that, in some instances, they prevented the children from attending school.  In addition, the complaint alleges, DOE failed to adequately evaluate the needs of the disabled students, including J.P., M.C., and O.A., who suffered from a rare genetic disorder that causes muscle spasms, hydrocephaly, and frequent severe seizures.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, the DOE and OHHS have agreed to settle the case by consenting to the entry of final judgments permanently enjoining them from future violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and ordering the DOE to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, a civil penalty, and an officer-and-director bar.  Additionally, the settlement is subject to court approval.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-8221 (Aug. 5, 2016).
